Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with reminders about tonight’s family dinner. My stepbrother had sent a photo of the table already set, and my stepmother’s message was clear: “It means a lot to us if you’re here.” I knew how important these gatherings were, especially since I’d promised to make more of an effort to bond with them. But just as I was about to leave the hospital, my pager went off—an emergency. A patient had come in with a rapidly spreading infection, and the nurse’s voice was urgent: “We need you to assess and prescribe treatment now.” I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My family expected my presence, my effort to belong. My patient needed my expertise, my responsibility as a doctor. I stood frozen in the hallway, torn between the warmth of a family dinner and the cold, clinical urgency of the ER, my heart pounding as I wrestled with which part of myself I would have to let down tonight.
